ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: the skills required to carry conversations, read, and present in Spanish.
I expanded my vocabulary, sentence structure, and use of tenses in Spanish. I feel that my writing improved especially, but my speaking skills also improved significantly.

I learned a lot more Spanish grammar, really advancing my skills to a more quasi-fluent level. I feel that after Spanish 120, I have the knowledge of vocabulary and grammar to fluently read and write Spanish.
New tenses, a lot more vocabulary, improved speaking and writing

I was able to develop my oral Spanish skills as well as expand my ability to communicate in various different scenarios and situations. I was also able to learn more about various different Spanish speaking countries.
I learned interpersonal and grammatical Spanish.
I learned a lot of Spanish grammar and gained better speaking skills and confidence in Spanish.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The professor is very kind and approachable. Makes the class room environment great for all.

Strengths: The consistent engagement with material in Spanish (speaking, reading, and writing)! Class discussion were low pressure, which I feel facilitated more participation (and thus improvement of speaking skills). 

Weaknesses: I did feel the turn around for weekly presentations was a bit too quick and, personally, speaking in these more high-pressure situations on a weekly basis in the first half of the semester didn't really improve my speaking skills. I felt that more low-pressure class-based discussion were more useful in this regard.

A strength is the asynchronous days on Wednesdays, which allowed a change of pace and an opportunity to learn in a different manner. A weakness was the sometimes arbitrary and tedious daily VHL homework. The assigned work did not always follow what we were learning in class. It felt as if a VHL course were designed separately from the Spanish course we took in class. The professor had no idea what was assigned on VHL, as it appeared to be under a domain separate from our classroom.

Strength: the supersite assignments are very helpful

Weaknesses: it goes so quickly through vocab and tenses without enough practice despite already having daily homework and other assignments. I would appreciate more interactive activities in the class aside from filling out so many black-and-white pdfs on Canvas.
The strengths of this course is that you are continually building on concepts and ideas.

This course could be improved by focusing a bit less on grammar and stoic presentations and more on an understanding of how to speak the language fluidly and spontaneously. However, it did yield a great environment for students to become grammatically proficient.

Strengths: The course is well designed to incorporate useful discussion topics while giving you the grammar to deepen your knowledge. I also liked the workload set up of the course; the beginning of the semester had a lot of individual mini presentations and then right near Thanksgiving break we presented our large group projects which made the ending feel really rewarding and less stressful (I was able to better focus on the project without the stress of other finals) and we ended with making our own play which was fun!
Weaknesses: Sometimes the partner work is hard to coordinate with due to Yalie's schedules -- try to know in advance if there is a partner assignment for the week so scheduling isn't an added hurdle.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I honestly really disliked having to take a language course at Yale. If you already have a heavy workload with other classes, spanish gets pushed to the back burner and feels more like a chore than something you can and should actually enjoy.
I would recommend this course if you need to take it for your language credit.
Yes! Spanish is a great language and important to develop the foundation in Spanish 120.

If you are looking to fulfill a language requirement and are interested in learning Spanish, I would recommend this course. It'll get the job done, and overall, was pretty enjoyable. The seminar setting facilitates useful class discussion to improve speaking skills, and the cultural concepts (which many assignments focus on) are interesting (or, at least, I found them to be).
I would recommend SPAN 120, as the course really helps advance Spanish language skills. I would caution the student about the nature of the VHL assignments not following along with the class.
I would recommend this course to others students. It is a great opportunity to expand your knowledge in a way that will be fruitful.
Yes, I would. It is L2 is a great way to learn the language conventions and grammar.
Yes! I've really enjoyed learning Spanish at Yale.
